channel.title: 华尔街日报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Omicron was able to elude two doses of the Covid-19 vaccine from Pfizer and BioNTech in initial lab testing, but three doses neutralized the variant, the companies said https://t.co/efJcH1q2Lx
One container ship waited nearly two months to dock at port. Here’s what the delay meant for small businesses with chess sets, holiday boots and other products stuck on board. https://t.co/bomQKQxD5g
Australia is joining the U.S. in a diplomatic boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing https://t.co/gCRcmaUwMw
The United Arab Emirates is shifting to a 4½-day workweek that will start Monday and end on Friday at noon https://t.co/sgz89dNcdr
A U.S. judge on Tuesday blocked the Biden administration’s Covid-19 vaccine mandate for employees of federal contractors https://t.co/FBUE9wljht

U.S. voters are pessimistic about the economy and short on confidence in President Biden’s leadership, a new WSJ Poll finds, a warning for Democrats entering a midterm election year https://t.co/mtDVlcpYEQ

Actor Laura Dern, known for her roles in "Big Little Lies," "Little Women" and "Marriage Story," wakes up at 6:30 a.m. and makes an effort to not pick up her phone first thing. She meditates for a few minutes instead. https://t.co/R9wRqQCp8p
Rohingya refugees sued Facebook parent Meta Platforms for $150 billion, alleging the social-media platform perpetuated the genocide against the Muslim ethnic group in Myanmar https://t.co/3coTVUIHTj
Amazon Web Services, the cloud-computing unit of Amazon, appeared to be down for thousands of users Tuesday morning https://t.co/GYnmAfn1OO

CNN won’t pay anchor Chris Cuomo a severance after firing him amid revelations that he helped his brother, Andrew Cuomo, respond to allegations of sexual harassment, the network’s president told employees https://t.co/vvkpMSeilA

Nobuo Matsubara still remembers being told in January 1942 that his brother, a Japanese navy ensign, had been killed in the attack on Pearl Harbor. It wasn’t true. But under the values of the time, the truth was even worse https://t.co/pjp3LmTax7

From @WSJopinion: History can be cruel to candidates for President who lose, but Bob Dole’s contributions to American life far exceeded his failed campaigns for the White House https://t.co/MJM68exDPl
The governor of Hawaii declared a state of emergency as pounding rainfall hits the tropical islands, causing flooding and power outages in some places https://t.co/zJ3df6pliB
Big wage increases are in store for next year. A new report shows companies budgeting the most for raises since 2008. https://t.co/7crjPLbYE2
U.S. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg speaks with WSJ’s @catherine_lucey at #WSJCEOCouncil https://t.co/DJ68z02nZG
From @WSJopinion: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio’s vaccine mandate for all workers is an infringement on liberty and a strike against the city, not the virus. https://t.co/6SXhsV218I

Evergrande didn’t make payments due on some U.S. dollar bonds before a final deadline expired Monday, people familiar with the matter said, potentially setting the stage for a massive default and one of the country’s largest-ever debt restructurings https://t.co/ZBPSAPLVdl

“Honestly, I would just can this whole bill.” Tesla CEO Elon Musk criticized federal efforts meant to spur electric-vehicle adoption, including a bill that would boost incentives for buying battery-powered cars #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/yeiEt1CcZt
Disappearing court documents. Restricted access to data on ships and supplies. China closes off details about what’s happening inside the country. https://t.co/qzYQo1pM83

Indian and Russian officials rejected American pressure to downgrade their close defense ties as the two countries’ leaders met in New Delhi and agreed to extend military technical cooperation for another decade https://t.co/Tv5I3uxMiQ

Saudi Arabia is running out of the ammunition to defend against drone and missile attacks from the Houthi rebels in Yemen, and is appealing to the U.S. and its Gulf and European allies for a resupply https://t.co/vabKKjCkKg
Watch: Investors are pouring money into the meme-based cryptocurrency Shiba Inu Coin, WSJ retail investing reporter Caitlin McCabe explains why https://t.co/7UE5m3EZvt
Apple’s vision for life after the iPhone is coming into view, writes @mims https://t.co/B0mrbPZrc8
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/fA0aW0ZKcp
President Biden will warn Russia's Vladimir Putin not to invade Ukraine in a call scheduled Tuesday, officials said https://t.co/VhwEZLTIkl

Millennials, feeling their mortality during Covid-19, start writing their wills. “It was a game-changer when my wife asked me if I’d want to be put on a ventilator if I needed one.” https://t.co/83vBl84PgW
Tesla and SpaceX founder Elon Musk speaks with WSJ’s @JoannaStern at #WSJCEOCouncil https://t.co/OiyO7UJuMz https://t.co/0xUmYBJH9b
Jack in the Box is buying Del Taco Restaurants for $455 million, a deal that ties up two West Coast fast-food chains https://t.co/glSbReA02d
Entrepreneurs are working to enable consumers to control and benefit from the personal data that the tech industry collects https://t.co/yM61Mzp9yG
The number of married couples who live apart is small but growing. Here’s how they say the arrangement helps their families and their relationships. https://t.co/doNp9uD85D
From @WSJopinion: Iran and Russia give every sign they don’t take President Biden seriously https://t.co/k2Mg1rhZmn
Toyota is investing $1.25 billion and creating 1,750 jobs with a new electric-vehicle battery plant in rural Randolph County, N.C. https://t.co/oTUnzQKjcM
The U.S. won't send officials to attend the coming Winter Olympics in Beijing. An announcement on the diplomatic boycott is expected this week. https://t.co/zF4x89X56K
The Biden administration unveiled steps to combat corruption globally, including new rules on U.S. real-estate purchases to prevent money laundering https://t.co/8fnDdJSTqM
Myanmar’s Aung San Suu Kyi is sentenced to four years in prison https://t.co/HLS0nhtyK0

Breaking: New York City will require all private-sector workers to be fully vaccinated against Covid-19, Mayor Bill de Blasio said. The new mandate will go into effect Dec. 27. https://t.co/4vGlgF5kJa
How Elon Musk became a high-profile cheerleader of China's Communist Party https://t.co/IhbzquXPZi
Russia and India set to reinforce defense ties at a summit meeting, as the U.S. considers sanctions over New Delhi’s purchase of a Russian missile system https://t.co/KmoBtLlCGO

High inflation has been blamed on supply-chain bottlenecks, labor shortages and the effects of fiscal stimulus, but there’s another factor at work—a shift away from globalization https://t.co/ahBtzvLOC1
Myanmar’s Aung San Suu Kyi was found guilty and sentenced to four years in prison in the first verdicts in a raft of charges brought by the military https://t.co/pzaz55oIxU
China wants to put its first Atlantic military base in Equatorial Guinea, U.S. intelligence shows. The prospect has set off alarm bells in Washington. https://t.co/hO08mBbRsY
Netflix announced its 2022 lineup, which includes new seasons of “Stranger Things” and “The Umbrella Academy” https://t.co/ydMlvGWmTl

“I am very lucky in my life that I have benefited from second chances, and I am aware that other people don’t even get first chances.” Ben Affleck talks Jennifer Lopez, fame, infamy, addiction and finally getting satisfaction—or as close to it as he’ll get https://t.co/R570DXyLPI
A New England Patriots linebacker and his wife turn NFL trades into investment opportunities #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/bJXp6pWh35 https://t.co/cEHTEY2WCe

An explosion shook the area near Iran’s main nuclear-enrichment plant late on Saturday, prompting conflicting explanations from Iranian officials as Tehran engages in talks with world powers over its nuclear program https://t.co/zlUZc0dSlv

New surveys from the U.S. Labor Department show exactly who is quitting—or thinking about quitting—as part of The Great Resignation: low-wage workers, employees of color and women not in management https://t.co/QqksO8dwkW
U.S. workers handed in nearly 20 million resignations this spring and summer. "Everybody quitting is saying, 'I became part of the Great Resignation.' " https://t.co/9UqslINCYp
Bob Dole, a fixture on the Washington scene for more than half a century and a national leader of the Republican Party, died at 98 https://t.co/XlYeOqZzSJ

Some alumni groups, driven by politically moderate or conservative baby boomers, say college campuses have been overtaken by progressive groupthink—and they’re not sending any more checks until something is done about it https://t.co/9ZfWH9vT3w

From @WSJopinion: The Biden administration at some point will realize that its political fortunes are tied to a virus that isn’t going anywhere, writes @KimStrassel. The longer it takes to make a clean break, the likelier it is to succumb to Covid. https://t.co/VdVRAGj8Mt
